job_title: Employment in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: College has an Incredible Community and Amazing Benefits! They really care about their employees and the students.
cons: Takes a long time to get projects completed since they must be approved by so many different departments.

job_title: Instructional Support Specialist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: - Coworkers and students are (usually) great - Flexible work schedule - SPC obviously values education and accommodates for employees who wish to continue their studies - This is a great job to build your skillset
cons: - Low pay - Seasonal burnout (Fall is tough) - Disconnect between library and administration causes funding issues - Lack of stability - Stressful between semesters, as anything can happen following a budget change

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Most students are a pleasure to work with. I have some great coworkers in a few departments.
cons: We are continually being asked to do more and more for no extra compensation (even if you have years of consistent “exceeding expectations” on your annual employee evaluation). Recent compensation study pay increase was followed by a decrease in benefit coverage. I don’t know how else to put it, but there is a lot of “smoke and mirrors” at the institution. We say we have a program for something, but when you actually look at what we’re doing, the program activities are not really impacting students as much as they could. Working hard not smart for very minimal results. No autonomy or resources to fix things when we know what the solutions are!

review_title: Better Salaries, Some Improving Work Condition \Unheard By Leadership
job_title: Career in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: SPC genuinely cares about their students and are beginning to spread some of this care to employees. Our salaries have improved, especially for senior employees. My colleagues are a perk. Since COVID, we've become more collaborative and supportive of one another. Working for SPC feels less like a competition and more about helping the team shine. Middle management has greatly improved their leadership strategies. I'm happy leadership are getting workshops and other trainings regarding how to lead with compassion. The paid holiday perks are amazing! One week paid for Thanksgiving break, two weeks paid for for Winter Break, and one week for Spring Break.
cons: SPC seems to be cutting costs on our health benefits. The new Florida Blue plans coming are unreasonable in cost, especially for employees with families. Work/life balance at SPC is nonexistent. Senior leadership seems to have no concept of what we actually do & how hard we are working. The burden of expectation placed on us is impossible to fulfill. New systems are constantly being put in place that made doing our jobs more difficult. Unfortunately, there still appears to be a snitching culture between campus management directed at other campus' employees. Its piddly and stupid. SPC has hired pre admissions, a call center, and new cyber advisors that are completely inept at their jobs. I'm constantly fixing their mistakes, yet required to do virtual advisement and preadmissions, when my focus should be case management. Why were all the people hired if we're still doing their work?

job_title: in Clearwater, FL
pros: The only pro left is great co-workers
cons: Terrible, unaffordable benefits Culture has decline from 5 to 10 years ago Incompetent leadership Shockingly bad policies and procedures Favoritism Very low pay Overloaded with work No growth

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Clearwater, FL
pros: Many great co-workers and informational sessions.
cons: None, love working here at SPC

job_title: Research Analyst in Clearwater, FL

job_title: Library Assistant in Saint Petersburg Beach, FL
pros: Great staff, good hours, and decent pay for what’s required of you. Once trained, it’s a self-directed position. You know what needs to be done, so just do it. Almost invisible manager, so I received 95% of my trading and assigned work from “supervisor” aka longest tenured employee.
cons: I may not have seen the manager much, but the negative affect she had on some of the full time staff could be felt even by a peon like me. Manager did as little as possible, often could be found watching videos on her office laptop or taking a nap.

cons:

Management hire directors that has no experience that will sabotage projects.

job_title: College Admissions in Tarpon Springs, FL

job_title: Career & Academic Advisor in Saint Petersburg Beach, FL
pros: SPC offers two weeks of paid time off during Winter Break and one week of during spring break. Working with the diverse group of students is an absolute pleasure. Career & Academic Advisors get a lot of training to offer the best knowledge/advice to our students. I also really love how SPC has responded and adapted to COVID with virtual advising and still implementing mostly work from home policies.
cons:
Raises are non-existent, though I am thankful to have a job during a pandemic. Our College President has made strides to change SPC's culture to one of a "Community of Care". For students she has been successful, but there are major issues with managers across the system. Hiring nepotism, favoritism of employees who snitch & gossip to management about other employees is actually rewarded. SPC management creates a hostile atmosphere where employees are pitted against one another and a culture of distrust. 

While open bullying seems to be discouraged by the College President now, mangers behave passive aggressively towards those who are not favorites. Achievements of those are ignored. Coveted positions on counsels for restructuring things important to all of our jobs are only given to the favorites. Sadly, to become a favorite, your ethical code needs to be about as shallow as a teaspoon.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Florida Junction, GA
pros: Great students and other adjunct professors.
cons:
Pay is low. 
Support for adjuncts are minimum.

pros: Very student friendly...offer many services to benefit the students

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Clearwater, FL
pros: Working with this diverse group of mature students is very rewarding. I come home from work feeling good about what I have accomplished that day. The faculty and most of the staff are wonderful to work with. There are a lot of caring faculty and staff at SPC. The benefits and time off are good. However, new employees are stuck with the high deductible insurance plan now.
cons: Mid-level management is terrible and very inexperienced, lacking true leadership skills.  Upper level management makes a show at listening to staff and advisors, but in the end only implements their own bottom line. Advisors have beyond full plates--there aren't enough hours in the day to get done all of the work assigned (even if advisors frequently stay late), but management will always add more duties completely unrelated to advising. The work environment is oppressive. I only stay because I love the students, faculty, and colleagues.

job_title: ESL Instructor in Clearwater, FL
pros: I taught English for Academic Purposes (EAP).. I taught adult students reading skills, grammar, and reading comprehension in their somewhat decent English Language program. The other ESL instructors were very nice and helpful when an instructor was hired part-time. The Academic Chair was somewhat friendly and tried to be helpful.
cons: When EAP students did not make the preferred grade, they would go the office and complained to the Academic Chair Instead of talking with the instructor. Because the department wanted to retain their EAP students, the Academic Chair would side with the students and discount what the instructors would say.

job_title: Academic in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Constantly innovating, great opportunities to make significant contributions at all levels of the college. The student population is also one of the best things about working there. The focus is on the students and getting them the skills they need to enter the workforce.
cons: Hard to advance. Promotions from within are discouraged in some departments which is counterintuitive especially when you have employees that have been with the college for some time that want to stay and take on more responsibility. Its a great work environment, though, so if you're patient its worth it. Very stable institution.

job_title: Student Assistant in Clearwater, FL
pros:
Understanding and flexible Supervisor
Ease of communication with department members
Opportunity to travel and conduct event coverage
Opportunity to meet with guests professionally 
Ability to work remote one day a week
Positive & Realistic work culture
Spring & Winter Breaks
cons:
Due to the sheer size of the University, communication stress can rise from outside departments. It can also get busy and fast-paced.

It is also an office job - so whenever you aren't on the field photographing or handling PR, you're sitting down at a computer. This can be a bummer for some, but the responsibilities were balanced enough that it didn't drag me out.  Weekly responsibilities become less of a drone and more of a muscle reflex.

Small-medium team, so responsibility can get heavy as deadlines meet.

job_title: Research Analyst in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
Great benefits and reasonable pay for the area. Plus paid time off for the major holidays and a Spring Break in March. 

Many who work there started in OPS partnerships or have worked in multiple departments so there are movement opportunities within.
cons: The interoffice politics is worse in some departments than others. Depending on what level the players involved are in, this can lead to a toxic work environment where it feels like your actions are constantly being watched. The departments where this is an issue are few based on my experience.

review_title: Try to get a living wage, a raise, or a cost of living increase.
job_title: Administrative Services Specialist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Additional paid time off when college is closed for Winter and Spring Break
cons: Administrative support starting salaries are insultingly low for the level and quantity of work expected.   Hard for a grown adult to get by on $14 or $15 an hour.  Also, no raises or cost of living increases in YEARS.

review_title: Adjunct Faculty not valued for their considerable contributions to SPC successes

review_title: Sad to be let go, great experience!
